awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The science of language and the language of science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. It has both scientific and societal benefits, and integrates research and education. This REU site trains students in hands-on skills in research methods and informal science learning. Students will work on language science research projects investigating how language is used in a social context, how children learn to use language in context, and how language understanding is integrated with other aspects of cognition, such as attention and memory. They will also learn how to explain complex scientific concepts to the general public in an engaging and accessible way. Training future researchers to communicate effectively is a critical need for maintaining a healthy long-term societal commitment to good science.

The Language Sciences Research Lab is a glass-enclosed space within a premier science museum, in which Ohio State faculty and students conduct cutting-edge work at the intersection of rigorous linguistic analysis, social interaction, and cognitive processing. Museum visitors are able to witness and learn about the studies in progress and are invited to join in the process as research participants. The REU site provides students with an integrated experience that trains students in both missions of the lab: how to conduct language science research and how to communicate with the public about science. Students experience classroom training in linguistics and psychology and in informal science education, research activities, and hand-on work on the museum floor engaging the public using interactive demonstrations of key language science concepts. The REU site expands the lab's undergraduate engagement from the Ohio State Columbus campus students to students from regional campus and community colleges who might not otherwise be able to be involved. At the end of the program, each student prepares and presents a research poster and a novel interactive demo.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported three cohorts of 10 college students who spent their summers learning to do linguistics and language science research and talk to the public about science. The students were majoring in a range of disciplines, most often psychology, speech and hearing science, linguistics and anthropology. Most, though not all, attended smaller schools whose opportunities for hands-on research were more limited. Students were trained in linguistics and informal science methods in the classroom, then assigned to faculty research mentors who had ongoing projects in need of assistance. Some of the projects included:
  • Adjusting Teaching Styles in Children
  • Best Match: Automatic Imitation across Dialects of American English
  • Conscious Accommodation and the BATH/TRAP Split
  • The Effect of Parent-Parent Social Capital on Children?s Narrative Language
  • The Effects of Children?s Encoding of Talker-Specific Information
  • How Children Use Information in Stories to Tell Time
  • How Gestures Influence the Mental Representation of Plurals
  • The Influence of Visual Salience of the Processing of Plurals
  • Informal Language Science Learning in a Museum Setting
  • Older Children?s Comprehension of Language out of Order
  • The Perception of Regional Dialects and Nonnative Accents in Children and Adults
  • Sociolinguistic Perception in Real Time
After the initial focus on classroom instruction, students split their time between research tasks and science outreach. For their research projects, they guided participants through the research tasks, prepared stimuli, analyzed data and other relevant activities. During their outreach time, they worked on the floor of Columbus's Center of Science and Industry (COSI), engaging museum visitors in interactive demos about language. In the 2021 cohort, which was conducted virtually, students learned about online science communication instead of in-person outreach.
 
At the end of each summer program, students presented conference-style research posters explaining their project and the results to date, as well as their own interactive outreach activities (or informal science videos, in the case of the 2021 cohort)in a capstone event. OSU students, faculty and staff and COSI staff attended these events along with the friends and family of local students.
 
In addition to the core research and outreach work, students attended workshops on a variety of professionalization topics, like preparing CVs, selecting and managing mentors, considering graduate school and navigating stereotype threat. They also had informal lunches with OSU phd students and faculty, former interns in the program and local professionals, in order to expand their professional networks and introduce them to a variety of people with different professional paths.
 
After the program, students reported increased confidence in their knowledge and skills in linguistics, the research process and informal science. Many of them have stayed in touch with the research mentors or other faculty they met through the program and roughly a third have gone on to graduate study in a related field.
